text: These are people who certainly have not proved that they are worthy of the trust that we repose in them. As far as this job is concerned, let me also indicate that when it comes to BECE, most of the decisions are taken by the Ghana Education Service. For example, the selection of supervisors and invigilators is done by the district exams officer, he explained. His comments come in the wake of a JoyNews Hotline investigation led by GH Probe’s Francisca Enchil, which uncovered disturbing levels of collusion at examination centres.
translated: [Batho ba ba sa reetseng gore ba kgatlhegile go nna le tshwanelo ya kgotsa ya rena. Ka ntlha ya tiro eno, ke re ke leboge gore fa e le BECE, tshwetso e nngwe e dirwa ke Ghana Education Service. Ka sekai, tlhopho ya babusi le baemeli ba dirwa ke ofisi ya tiro ya ditswammung. A bua a le mo tseleng ya tshwetso ya JoyNews Hotline e e dirilweng ke GH Probe’s Francisca Enchil, e e neng e bulela maemo a go kgatlhegana mo dikokelweng tsa tiro.]
backtranslated: [For those who are not interested in having the right to our. For this work, let me thank that in the case of BECE, the other decision is made by the Ghana Education Service. For example, the selection of governors and representatives is made by the office of human resources work. Speaking on the way to the decision of JoyNews Hotline made by GH Probes Francisca Enchil, which opened up the positions of interest in the work associations.]

text: A variety of socioeconomic and cultural factors were identified as major barriers to accessing and utilizing MHCS. Over half of the women surveyed cited poverty, illiteracy, restrictions from their husbands, the distance to health facilities, and long queues as reasons for not using services. Additionally, over a third of the women pointed to cultural practices within their communities as a cause for delays in seeking care. These findings reveal that addressing maternal health in this region requires more than just improving clinical services; it also means tackling deeply rooted societal and personal challenges that women face daily.

text: Despite his shortcomings, Unoka was a talented musician. He was a tall but very thin man with a slight stoop and a mournful look, which would disappear when he was drinking or playing his flute. His happiest moments came in the months after the harvest, when the village musicians would retrieve their instruments from above the fireplace. Unoka would join them, his face filled with pure joy and peace. Sometimes, other villages would invite Unoka and his band to teach them their tunes, and they would stay for several months, sharing their music.

text: At the Derby Avenue RC Basic School and St. George’s Anglican Basic School in Accra, invigilators were captured openly demanding GH¢60 daily tokens, supervisors pocketed envelopes of GH¢400, and candidates were asked to contribute to an Aseda Offertory. John Kapi stressed that once WAEC provides feedback on such incidents, it is the responsibility of the Ghana Education Service (GES) to take decisive action. And so when these issues come up, once the feedback goes to them, we [WAEC] expect that they would react appropriately and ensure that the right action is taken against the people, he said.
translated: [Go tsebeng kwa Derby Avenue RC Basic School le St. George’s Anglican Basic School kwa Accra, bafuputsi ba ne ba kgethwa ba bitsa kwa tshwanelo tokene ya GH¢60 ya letsatsi, bafuputsi ba ne ba tsenya dienvelopi tsa GH¢400 mo diaparo tsa bone, le batswakwa ba ne ba kopa gore ba tsenye Aseda Offertory. John Kapi o ne a gakolola gore fa WAEC e ne a fa feedback ka mafoko ao, e le karolo ya Ghana Education Service (GES) go tsaya maikemisetso a a tlhomphang. Le fa mafoko a a tsena, fa feedback e ya go bone, re [WAEC] re tshwenyegile gore ba tlaa araba sentle le go tsaya maikemisetso a a tlhomphang go lwantsha batho bao, a re.]
backtranslated: [At the hearing at Derby Avenue RC Basic School and St. George's Anglican Basic School in Accra, the researchers were selected to correctly call a GH¢60 token for the day, the researchers put GH¢400 envelopes in their clothes, and the foreigners asked to include the Aseda Offertory. John Kapi advised that when the WAEC gave feedback on those words, it was part of the Ghana Education Service (GES) taking decisive action. Even if the words come in, when the feedback goes to them, we [WAEC] are concerned that they will respond well and take decisive action against those people, he said.]

text: For rural communities in Ghana, especially in the Kumbungu district, access to and use of maternal healthcare services (MHCS) remain a significant challenge. This study set out to explore the specific barriers preventing women from utilizing these services and to evaluate the quality of care provided. The research adopted a mixed-methods approach, combining both quantitative and qualitative data to get a comprehensive view of the situation. This phased design involved surveying 441 pregnant and postpartum women and conducting interviews with 20 healthcare providers. A facility checklist was also used to assess the state of clinics, including the availability of essential drugs and equipment.

text: Okonkwo was a man of great renown throughout his nine villages and even beyond, a fame built entirely on his own remarkable achievements. At just eighteen years old, he brought honor to his village by defeating Amalinze the Cat, a legendary wrestler who had been undefeated for seven years. Amalinze earned his nickname because his back never once touched the earth. The old men of the village considered Okonkwo's victory one of the fiercest fights they had ever seen.
translated: [Okonkwo e ne le monna wa kgosi ya go farologana mo metseng ya gagwe tse senyane, le go feta moo, kgosi e e neng e tsamaisiwa ke ditswele tsa gagwe tse di neng di le molemo. A na le dingwaga di le lesome le seswai, o ne a tlhomela motse wa gagwe kgosi ka go fenya Amalinze ya kgosi, mmoloki wa kgosi wa kgosi wa setso, yo o neng a sa fenwe ke motho wa kgosi wa kgosi wa setso go tloga go feta dingwaga tse di le lesome le boraro. Amalinze o ne a tlhomela leina la gagwe la kgosi wa kgosi wa setso ka go bolela gore sefako sa gagwe se ne se sa kgone go tshwana le lefatshe. Bana ba kgosi ba motse wa kgosi wa kgosi wa setso ba ne ba akanya gore kgosi wa kgosi wa setso wa Okonkwo e ne e le ya kgosi wa kgosi wa setso e e neng e le ya kgosi wa kgosi wa setso.]
backtranslated: [Okonkwo was the king's husband of distinction in his nine villages, and moreover, the king was accompanied by his good breasts. At the age of eighteen, he established a king for his village by defeating the king's Amalinze, the traditional king's savior, who had not been defeated by a traditional king's man for over thirteen years. Amalinze established his title of traditional king by stating that his crown could not match the earth. The children of the traditional king's village thought that the traditional king Okonkwo was the traditional king's son.]

text: Muntaka assured the committee of full logistical and secretariat support from the Ministry and urged them to partner with civil society organizations, development partners, and faith-based institutions in carrying out their work. He described the task as heavy but honorable, stressing that the people of Gbenyiri and surrounding communities were looking up to the committee as instruments of peace, reconciliation, and healing.
translated: [Muntaka o ne a tshwanela komiti ya tshepo ya kgwebo le ya sekretariete go tswa kwa Mphalane, a ba kopa gore ba tsamaye le setšhaba, baeti ba tshireletso le maphelo a setšhaba mo go diragatseng tiro ya bone. O ne a bua ka tiro e e le nngwe mme a e tlhomamisa e le ya boikanyego, a kgopela gore batho ba Gbenyiri le ditoropong tse di kgaogang di ba amogele e le dithuso tsa kagiso, kgwetlho le go phologa.]
backtranslated: [The peerage was for the trust committee of the trade and secretary from October, asking them to accompany the public, the security and public health visits in the discharge of their duties. He mentioned one mission and confirmed it as a trust, asking that the people of Gbenyiri and the adjoining towns accept them as a contribution to peace, challenge and salvation.]

text: The study also shed light on significant facility-based challenges that compromise the quality of care. A key issue was the inadequate number of midwives, which likely contributes to the long queues women reported. Additionally, the absence of essential equipment and drugs was a major problem. For example, health service providers specifically recommended a greater number of trained midwives and the provision of critical logistics like ultrasound machines and proper delivery equipment to ensure effective and high-quality care.

text: Okonkwo was an imposing figure, tall and massive with a severe expression, a result of his bushy eyebrows and wide nose. His breathing was so heavy that his family could hear it from their own houses when he slept. When he walked, his heels barely touched the ground, making him seem poised to pounce on someone—which he often did. He had a slight stammer, and in moments of anger, he would resort to his fists when words failed him. He had no patience for men who were not successful, and this sentiment stemmed from his deep-seated shame for his own father.
translated: [Okonkwo e ne e le motho wa kgolo, wa bogolo le wa kgotlhego, a neng a lebelela ka tsela e kgatlhisang, e e tswang ke diboa tsa gagwe tse di tshweu le tse di kgatlhang, tse di neng di mo kgatlhisa. Phefo ya gagwe e ne e le kgolo hela, gore lelapa la gagwe le ne la kgona go e utlwa mo ntlong ya bone fa a ne a robala. Fa a tsamaya, dihlo tsa gagwe di ne di kgona go feta mo lefatsheng, a mo kgatlhisang a tla go tshwara motho—e e ne e le selo se a neng a se dira kwa nako nngwe le nngwe. A ne a na le kgwetlho e kgolo, le fa a lebelela ka tsela e kgatlhisang, a ne a nna a tshwara ka diatla fa mafoko a gagwe a ne a se ka a mo kgona. A ne a se na kgatlhego go batla ba ba sa kgathalesego, le selo se a neng a se dira se ne se tswa mo kgatlhegong ya gagwe e kgatlhisang go ena lelapa la gagwe.]
backtranslated: [Okonkwo was a large, large and stout man, who had a fascinating look, which came from his white and interesting beards, which fascinated him. His breath was so large, that his family could hear it in their house when he slept. When he went, his calls could go across the world, his fascination to come and catch someone was something he did at any time and place. He had a great challenge, though he looked fascinating, he kept holding hands with people when his words did not impress him. He had no interest in those who were indifferent, and whatever he did was in his own interest and in the interest of his family.]

text: The West African Examinations Council (WAEC) says officials implicated in acts of corruption during the Basic Education Certificate Examination (BECE) will be blacklisted from ever taking part in its activities again. Speaking on JoyNews’ PM Express on September 8, WAEC’s Director of Public Affairs, John Kapi, said the Council cannot continue to work with individuals who have betrayed the trust placed in them during national examinations.
translated: [Setšhaba sa Afrika ya Bophirima sa Ditlhopho (WAEC) se re baemedi ba ba kwadilweng ka ditsweletso tsa kotsi mo ditlhophong tsa Sekolo sa Bokgoni (BECE) ba tla bolawa go tsenya karolo mo ditsweletsong tsa sona gape. A bua mo JoyNews’ PM Express ka la 8 September, Mokwaledi wa Ditiro tsa Setšhaba wa WAEC, John Kapi, o re Setšhaba ha se ke se tswelele go tshwara le baemedi ba ba ileng ba kgobokana ka tshwanelo e ba e neng ba e newa mo ditlhophong tsa naga.]
backtranslated: [The West African Electoral Commission (WAEC) says candidates listed with dangerous endorsements in the Bece Electoral College (BECE) elections will be killed to re-introduce them to its endorsements. Speaking on JoyNews PM Express on September 8, WAEC Public Affairs Secretary John Kapi says the Commission cannot continue to arrest candidates who have rallied with the right given to them in national elections.]

text: The study found that while a high percentage of women did engage with some maternal health services—87.5% attended antenatal care (ANC), 87.3% had a skilled delivery, and 84.8% had a postnatal care (PNC) visit—the frequency of care was a concern. A little over half of the participants (53.4%) had the recommended four or more ANC visits, and nearly half (46.9%) didn't register until their second trimester. These figures highlight a gap between initial access and consistent, timely utilization of services, suggesting that women may be facing obstacles that prevent them from fully engaging with the healthcare system throughout their pregnancies.
translated: [Thuto e ile ya faphega gore fa e le gore sekgala se segolo sa basadi se ne se kopana le dikamano tse dingwe tsa bophelo jwa basadi ba ba tsalang—87.5% ba ile go ya ANC, 87.3% ba ne ba na tshiamo ya go tsala, le 84.8% ba ne ba ya go ya PNC—kgwedi ya tsebe e ne e le kgwedi e e sa tshwaneng. Kgwedi e e kwa godimo ya nne ya badiri (53.4%) e ne ya ya ANC e e e reng e le nne kgotsa e e kwa godimo, le kgwedi e e kwa tlase ya nne (46.9%) e ne ya reng e sa tsene go fitlhela trimesta ya bobedi. Dikgwedi tse di bontsha kgwedi e e kwa tlase ya go tsena le go tsena ka nako, e bontsha gore basadi ba ka tshwarwa ke kgwedi e e sa tshwaneng go tsena ka tsela e e tseneleditsweng le go tsena ka nako ya dikamano tsa bophelo jwa basadi ba ba tsalang.]
backtranslated: [The study found that if the greater distance of women coincided with other maternal life relationships87.5% went to ANC, 87.3% had a fertility, and 84.8% went to PNCthe ear month was a different month. The highest month of the workers (53.4%) was ANC which said four or more, and the lowest month was (46.9%) which said not to have entered until the second trimester. The months indicate a lower month of entering and entering at the time, indicating that women have menstruation in a different way than the induced entering and entering during maternal life.]

text: The crowd held its breath as the drums beat and the flutes sang. Amalinze was a clever opponent, but Okonkwo was just as skilled, and as slippery as a fish in water. Both men were incredibly strong, their muscles and nerves straining to the point of almost breaking. But in the end, Okonkwo emerged victorious. This monumental win was just the beginning of his legacy. Over the next twenty years, his fame spread like a wildfire, fueled by his unwavering resolve and personal triumphs.

text: The seven-member mediation committee will be chaired by Mr. Emmanuel Habuka Bombande. Other members of the committee include Alhaji Collins Dauda (MP and chair of the Committee on Lands and Natural Resource in Parliament), Rev. Father Lazarus Annyere (Chair of Savannah Regional Peace Council), Dr. Festus Aubyn (West Africa Network for Peace-building), Sylvia Hormane Noagbesenu Esq (Ag. Director of Women, Youth, Peace and Security Institute, Kofi Annan International Peacekeeping Training Center), Prof. Ramatu Alhassan and Dr. George Amoh (Ex. Sec. NPC) who will be the secretary.
translated: [Komitee ya kgwetlho ya batshamele ba le masome a mabedi e tla tsamaisiwa ke Rre Emmanuel Habuka Bombande. Ba bangwe ba komitee e akaretsa Alhaji Collins Dauda (MP le tona ya Komiti ya Tshimo le Ntsho ya Setshaba), Rev. Father Lazarus Annyere (Tona ya Savannah Regional Peace Council), Dr. Festus Aubyn (West Africa Network for Peace-building), Sylvia Hormane Noagbesenu Esq (Ag. Director of Women, Youth, Peace and Security Institute, Kofi Annan International Peacekeeping Training Center), Prof. Ramatu Alhassan le Dr. George Amoh (Ex. Sec. NPC) yo a tla nna sekretari.]
backtranslated: [The challenge committee of twenty players will be chaired by Mr. Emmanuel Habuka Bombande. Other members of the committee include Alhaji Collins Dauda (MP and minister of the Field and Black Community Committee), Rev. Father Lazarus Annyere (Minister of the Savannah Regional Peace Council), Dr. Festus Aubyn (West Africa Network for Peace-building), Sylvia Hormane Noagbesenu Esq (Ag. Director of Women, Youth, Peace and Security Institute, Kofi Annan International Peacekeeping Training Center), Prof. Ramatu Alhassan and Dr. George Amoh (Ex. Sec. NPC) who will serve as the secretary.]

text: To improve maternal health in the Kumbungu district, both study participants and service providers offered actionable recommendations. Women suggested focusing on public education about maternal care, enforcing free MHCS, and improving the local road network to make facilities more accessible. Providers emphasized the need for more midwives and better equipment. The study concludes that both governmental and non-governmental organizations must increase investment in maternal health and address the broader socioeconomic issues affecting women. This comprehensive approach, tackling both healthcare system deficiencies and community-level barriers, is essential for truly improving maternal health outcomes.
translated: [Ka go fokotsa bophelo jwa basadi mo kgaolong ya Kumbungu, batho ba ba tseneletseng mo kgethong le ba ba emetseng mo go emetseng, ba ne ba kgothaletsa ditshwanelo tse di kgonegang. Basadi ba ne ba kopa gore go nne le thuto ya kgwele ya khansele ya basadi, go tshwanela go emetswa ka tlhwatlhwa ya kgwele ya basadi, le go fokotsa tsela ya kgwele ya khansele gore go nne le kgwele ya kgwele. Ba ba emetseng ba ne ba kopa gore go nne le ba ba emetseng ba basadi ba bantsi le kgwele ya kgwele e e kgonegang. Kgetho ke ya kwala gore mafapha a setshaba le a sekgowa a setshaba a swanela go fokotsa kgwele ya kgwele ya basadi le go tshwanela kgwele ya kgwele ya kgwele. Tsela e e kgonegang, e e tshwanetseng kgwele ya kgwele ya kgwele le kgwele ya kgwele, ke e e kgonegang go fokotsa kgwele ya kgwele ya basadi.]
backtranslated: [By reducing the life of women in Kumbungu district, the people involved in the elections and those representing them in the elections, promoted feasible rights. The women called for a women's football league education, a feasible representation in the women's league price, and a reduced league course to make the league feasible. The representatives called for more women's league representatives. The choice is that the national and local leagues should reduce the women's league and fit the national league. The feasible, feasible league and league course, is to allow for a reduced women's league.]

text: Unoka, Okonkwo's father, had passed away ten years prior. He was a man known for his laziness and carelessness, living only for the present with no thought for the future. Any money he managed to acquire—which was a rare occurrence—he would immediately spend on palm-wine, gathering his neighbors for a celebration. He believed that to see a dead man's mouth was to see the foolishness of not eating what you had in life. Unoka was also deeply in debt, owing money to nearly every one of his neighbors.
translated: [Unoka, rra wa Okonkwo, o ne a swa dingwaga tse le lesome pele. E ne e le monna wa go itsewa ka tshenyo le tlhakanelo, a phela fela ka nako ya gompieno a sa tlhakanele ka nako ya bokhutlo. Chelete a a nang a a ka kgona go e fetsa—e le nako e e se nne e le nngwe—o e ne a e fetsa ka mokgwa wa palm-wine, a bipa baagwe go tla go tshameka. O ne a dumela gore go bona mokgwa wa motho a suleng go bona tlhakanelo ya go ja se o se nang mo lefatsheng. Unoka o ne a le mo kgwetlhamong go baagwe ba le bantsi, a ba leka chelete.]
backtranslated: [Unoka, Okonkwo's father, had died ten years earlier. He was a man of notorious vandalism and sexism, living only in the present without participating in the end time. The money he could afford to spend - not even a single moment - he spent in the form of palm-wine, covering his mother for a game. He believed that seeing the dead man's form was a sexual opportunity to eat what was lacking in the world. Unoka was in a challenge to many, trying to make money.]
